reference.notes:
Elements References -------- ---------- .
The 6-311G part ---------------
H, Li - Ne: R. Krishnan, J.S. Binkley, R. Seeger and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 72, 650 (1980) Na - Ar: A.D. McLean and G.S. Chandler J. Chem. Phys. 72, 5639, (1980). K - Ca: J-P. Blaudeau, M. P. McGrath, L.A. Curtiss and L. Radom, J. Chem. Phys. 107, 5016 (1997).
The 6-311G* polarization functions ----------------------------------
Li - Ar: R. Krishnan, J.S. Binkley, R. Seeger, J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 72, 650 (1980). K - Ca: J-P. Blaudeau, M. P. McGrath, L.A. Curtiss and L. Radom, J. Chem. Phys. 107, 5016 (1997). The diffuse functions --------------------- H: (1s) T. Clark, J. Chandrasekhar, G.W. Spitznagel and P. von R. Li - Ne: (1s,1p) Schleyer. J. Comp. Chem. 4, 294 (1983). Na - Ar: (1s,1p) R. Krishnam, J.S. Binkley, R. Seeger, J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 72, 650 (1980). P.M.W. Gill, B.G. Johnson, J.A. Pople and M.J. Frisch, Chem. Phys. Lett. 197, 499 (1992). These exponents were optimized for 8 small anions using the 3-21G basis set at the HF level of theory by Clark et al. Frisch, Pople and Binkley reoptimized the exponents at the MP4 level for both neutral and anionic systems. The (s,p) sets employ shared exponents for better integral speed.
